{{Infobox officeholder |name = Craig E. Campbell |image = Craig Campbell.jpg |captionstyle = |caption = Campbell in 2008 |office = 10th [[Lieutenant Governor of Alaska]] |governor = Sean Parnell |term_start = August 10, 2009 |term_end = December 6, 2010 |predecessor = [[Sean Parnell]] |successor = [[Mead Treadwell]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|3|24}} |birth_place = [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |profession = Military Officer |alma_mater = [[University of Tulsa]]
[[Golden Gate University]]
[[Naval War College]] |spouse = Anne Marie Campbell |children = Amanda Campbell
Melanie Campbell |religion = |allegiance = [[United States]] |branch = [[United States Air Force]] |serviceyears = 1974–2009 |rank = [[Lieutenant General (United States)|Lieutenant General]] ([[Alaska National Guard]])
[[Major General (United States)|Major General]] ([[Air National Guard]]) |awards = (3) [[Legion of Merit|Air Force Meritorious Service Medal]]
(2) [[Air Force Commendation Medal]]
[[Outstanding Unit Award]]
[[Organizational Excellence Award|Air Force Organizational Excellence Award]]
[[National Defense Service Medal]]
(6) [[Air Force Longevity Service Award]]
Air Reserve Forces Service Medal
Alaska Distinguished Service Medal
Alaska Commendation Medal
California Medal of Merit }} '''Craig Eaton Campbell''' (born March 24, 1952){{cite web|url=http://www.courtrecords.alaska.gov/pa/pa.urd/pamw2000.o_party_sum?24927195|title=Testator (Will) - Summary (3AN-89-00077WI In the Matter of: Campbell, Craig Eaton)|work=CourtView|publisher=[[Alaska Court System]]|accessdate=September 30, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/celeb/craigcampbell.htm|title=craig campbell|work=Rootsweb|publisher=[[Ancestry.com]]|accessdate=September 30, 2011}} is an American politician and businessman and is the current president and chief executive officer of the Alaska Aerospace Corporation (AAC). He joined the corporation as chief operating officer in February 2011, and was appointed president and CEO by the Board of Directors in October 2012. [http://www.akaerospace.com/craig_campbell_bio.html] Prior to his position at AAC, Campbell was the [[List of Lieutenant Governors of Alaska|10th Lieutenant Governor of Alaska]], holding the office from August 10, 2009 through December 6, 2010.[http://www.adn.com/2010/12/05/1589557/parnell-sees-freedom-to-go-his.html Parnell sees freedom to go his own direction as governor ''Becky Bohrer, Associated Press 12-6-2010''] Pending his confirmation by the State Legislature, he was "temporary substitute" lieutenant governor for several weeks.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.state.ak.us/news.php?id=5012 |title=Sean Parnell, 10th Governor of Alaska |publisher=Gov.state.ak.us |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-09-04}}{{cite web|url=http://www.juneauempire.com/stories/081109/sta_480557053.shtml |title=Campbell answers concerns, wins strong approval |publisher=Juneau Empire |date= |accessdate=2010-09-04}} Campbell left office in December 2010, after having withdrawn from the Republican primary race for lieutenant governor,[http://community.adn.com/node/150993 Campbell Won't Run for Lieutenant Governor] which was eventually won by [[Mead Treadwell]]. Before serving as lieutenant governor, Campbell was the commissioner of the [[Alaska Department of Military and Veterans Affairs]]. In that role, he was head of the state's National Guard, with the rank of Lieutenant General.National Guard Bureau. [http://www.ngb.army.mil/ngbgomo/library/bio/1040.htm "Major General Craig E. Campbell"], ngb.army.mil. November 2006. Retrieved July 4, 2009. On July 3, 2009, Alaska Governor [[Sarah Palin]] announced that she would resign effective July 26. Lieutenant Governor [[Sean Parnell]] would become governor, and Campbell would replace Parnell as [[Lieutenant Governor of Alaska|lieutenant governor]].{{cite news | first=MSNBC | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Gov Palin to resign her office | date= | publisher= | url =http://www.ktuu.com/Global/story.asp?S=10641495 | work =[[KTUU-TV]] | pages = | accessdate = 2009-07-03 | language = }}[http://media.adn.com/smedia/2009/07/03/12/Palinpressrelease.20427.source.prod_affiliate.7.pdf “Governor Palin Announces No Second Term, No Lame Duck Session Either,”] Press Release, Office of the Governor, Via ''[[Anchorage Daily News]]'' (2009-07-03). In 2010, Campbell opted to not seek election as lieutenant governor, preferring to return to the business sector and joining AAC in February 2011. Campbell was appointed the state chair for the Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve (ESGR) Alaska State Committee in October 2012. [http://www.akaerospace.com/craig_campbell_bio.html] He is married to wife Anne Marie and has two children: Amanda and Melanie (deceased), and four grandchildren: Faith, Ellie, Kimberly and Emma.[[Alaska Department of Military and Veterans Affairs]]. [http://dmva.alaska.gov/biographies/campbell.htm "Commissioner Campbell Biography"], dmva.alaska.gov. March 12, 2009. Retrieved July 4, 2009. ==Biography== Campbell was born in 1952.Inklebarger, Timothy. "Murkowski names Campbell military chief", ''Juneau Empire''. December 30, 2002. State and Regional section. He was raised in [[Longmeadow, Massachusetts]] and attended the [[University of Tulsa]] in [[Oklahoma]] on a Reserve Officer's Training Corp. ([[ROTC]]) scholarship, and graduated in 1974 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[political science]]. He was commissioned a [[second lieutenant]] that year and was assigned to the Air Traffic Control Officers Training Course at [[Keesler Air Force Base]] in [[Mississippi]]. After being certified as an [[air traffic controller]], he was assigned to [[Travis Air Force Base]] in [[California]], then to [[K. I. Sawyer Air Force Base]] in [[Michigan]]. Each assignment brought a promotion, and he left Sawyer in 1979 as a [[Captain (United States)|captain]]. From Sawyer, he moved to [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]], where he served as chief of air traffic control operations until 1981. During his stay at Vandenberg, he attended classes and earned a [[Master of Public Administration]] degree from [[Golden Gate University]] in nearby [[San Francisco, California]]. In 1981, he was assigned to Alaska for the first time when he was named the chief of air traffic control operations with the 1930th Communications Squadron at Elmendorf Air Force Base in [[Anchorage]]. He left active-duty U.S. Air Force, joined the [[California Air National Guard]], and was assigned duties at [[Hayward Air National Guard Base]] in that state in 1984. In addition, he worked extensively in the private sector, with over 15 years of aviation consulting experience including airport master planning, environmental planning, economic feasibility studies, and facilities location planning—both in the U.S. and internationally.http://www.akaerospace.com/craig_campbell_bio.html Campbell has been active in Alaskan politics since being first elected to the [[City council|Assembly]] 1986, when he was first elected to the Anchorage Assembly, representing the [[Chugiak]], [[Eagle River (Anchorage)|Eagle River]], Birchwood, Peters Creek, Eklutna, and Mountain View sections of Anchorage. The district also included Elmendorf and the other major military base in Anchorage, Fort Richardson (the two have since been combined as [[Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson]]).Holland, Megan. [http://www.adn.com/politics/story/852915.html "Craig Campbell to replace Parnell"], ''Anchorage Daily News''. July 3, 2009. Retrieved July 4, 2009. He subsequently was re-elected in 1989 and 1992, serving twice as Chairman of the Assembly. In 1991, he joined the Alaska National Guard and became commander of the 168th Resource Management Squadron at [[Eielson Air Force Base]] in Alaska. He later was made commander of the 168th Logistics Squadron at the base and was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]]. In 1994, Campbell unsuccessfully ran for Mayor of Anchorage, coming in third out of a field of fourteen candidates in the non-partisan, municipality-wide election.http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=489438 He later served on the Matanuska Electric Association Board of Directors from 1996 - 2000,http://www.apfboardconfirmation.org/campbell.html and as an adjunct professor for Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University from 1990 - 2000. In 1997, he moved into a staff position with the Alaska Air National Guard in Anchorage. In 1999, he earned a [[Master of Arts]] degree in [[national security]] and [[strategic studies]] from the [[Naval War College]] at Newport, Rhode Island. He stayed in staff positions until 2000, when he was promoted to [[colonel]] and named vice commander of the [[168th Air Refueling Wing]] at Eielson. While there, he helped command the wing's operations in support of the American war effort in Afghanistan.Ipsen, Beth. "Latitude adjustment - 168th Air Refueling Wing has dual duty in Alaska, Guam", ''Fairbanks Daily News-Miner''. March 17, 2002. Page A1. The same year that he was named vice-commander, he became executive director of Anchorage's Office of Planning, Development and Public Works.The Associated Press. "Ex-Assemblyman to lead Army, Air Guard", ''Anchorage Daily News''. December 31, 2002. Page B1. In 2003, he was selected by then-Alaska governor [[Frank Murkowski]] to serve as the state's adjutant general—the commander of the Alaska National Guard—and commissioner of the [[Alaska Department of Military and Veterans Affairs]]. Following Palin's election in 2006, he was reconfirmed in his office. Campbell has 35 years of aerospace experience in the USAF and Alaska National Guard, during which he oversaw the Alaska Army National Guard development of missile defense operations and security missions at Ft. Greely, AK; the relocation of Kulis Air National Guard Base to Joint Base Elmendorf-Richardson; the formation of an associate flying unit between the USAF and Alaska Air National Guard for operations of the C-17 Globemaster III strategic airlift transport; and establishment of a state partnership between the Alaska National Guard and the country of Mongolia. Campbell was promoted to lieutenant (three-star) general within the state National Guard by Palin on September 7, 2008. He retained his federal National Guard rank of major (two-star) generalState of Alaska. [http://www.gov.state.ak.us/news.php?id=1449 "Alaska NG Adjutant General Promoted"], gov.state.ak.us. September 8, 2008. Retrieved July 4, 2009. until he retired August 31, 2009.National Guard Bureau. [http://www.ng.mil/ngbgomo/library/bio/1040.htm], www.ngb.mil. Retrieved December 1, 2010. Campbell became the president and chief executive officer for Alaska Aerospace Corporation in 2012. ==Lieutenant governor== Under the Alaska state constitution, a governor's selection of a new lieutenant governor is subject to confirmation by the State Legislature. The same Constitution, however, gives the governor the power to make "recess appointments", and the Legislature was not in session when Parnell succeeded as governor on July 26. Following Palin's announcement, conflicting statements issued from Alaska legal authorities as to whether Parnell had the authority to appoint a lieutenant governor without approval from the state legislature. The state attorney general stated that while Palin could name Campbell lieutenant governor, it would be preferable to have him sworn in as acting or temporary lieutenant governor, taking the permanent post only upon approval of the legislature.{{cite web|url=http://www.juneauempire.com/stories/071209/loc_462410851.shtml |title=AG: Palin can appoint an 'acting' lieutenant governor |publisher=Juneau Empire |date= |accessdate=2010-09-04}}http://www.ktuu.com/Global/story.asp?S=10708481 Only July 26, after then-Lieutenant Governor Parnell was sworn in as governor, Campbell was given the oath as "temporary substitute" lieutenant governor. The oath was administered by [[Alaska Supreme Court]] Justice Daniel E. Winfree. After coming back into session, the Legislature confirmed Campbell as lieutenant governor by a vote of 55-4. ==See also== * [[Miller v. Campbell]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{S-start}} {{S-off}} {{S-bef|before = [[Sean Parnell]]}} {{S-ttl| title = [[Lieutenant Governor of Alaska]]|years=2009–2010}} {{S-aft| after = [[Mead Treadwell]]}} {{S-end}} {{AlaskaLtGovernors}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Campbell, Craig}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Alaska Republicans]] [[Category:Anchorage Assembly members]] [[Category:Golden Gate University alumni]] [[Category:Lieutenant Governors of Alaska]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:National Guard of the United States officers]] [[Category:Naval War College alumni]] [[Category:People from Hampden County, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:State cabinet secretaries of Alaska]] [[Category:United States Air Force officers]] [[Category:University of Tulsa alumni]] [[Category:American chief operating officers]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:Air traffic controllers]]
